docs.snippet: For the hot dogs and hamburgers at your Labor Day cookout, there are some unusual condiments made in South Africa. So!Go Relish (subtitled fruit chutney), above left, is a bright sweet-and-sour mixture that throws off a touch of heat. Sweet Chili,...
docs.abstract: Comment on some unusual condiments made in South Africa; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: For the hot dogs and hamburgers at your Labor Day cookout, there are some unusual condiments made in South Africa. So!Go Relish (subtitled fruit chutney), above left, is a bright sweet-and-sour mixture that throws off a touch of heat. Sweet Chili, above right, has more serious Sichuan leanings, and Catch'Up tomato sauce, in the rear, is earthier than Heinz's. The cute seven-ounce frosted bottles are convenient enough to take on a picnic, which might even make sense for the company's olive oil and soy sauce. Prices are $6.29 to $6.99 at Grace's Marketplace, Garden of Eden and Zabar's.

docs.snippet: The lease has been signed: now all they need is a name. VICKI FREEMAN and MARC MEYER, below, who own FIVE POINTS in NoHo, are taking over a space in Chelsea, at 156 10th Avenue (20th Street), which they plan to turn into a 140-seat restaurant this...
docs.abstract: Vicki Freeman and Marc Meyer, owners of NoHo restaurant Five Points, have signed lease for space in Chelsea; roundup of other activity in restaurant industry; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The lease has been signed: now all they need is a name. VICKI FREEMAN and MARC MEYER, below, who own FIVE POINTS in NoHo, are taking over a space in Chelsea, at 156 10th Avenue (20th Street), which they plan to turn into a 140-seat restaurant this year. Mr. Meyer, who is the chef at Five Points, plans to use a wood-burning rotisserie to prepare rustic dishes, like herb-stuffed leg of lamb, and to change the menu daily. PACIFIC GRILL, a pan-Asian seafood restaurant, has opened on Pier 17 in the South Street Seaport. The chef, YOGESH SODHI, worked in India, Kenya and Canada, and is serving dishes like crisp duck leg confit with pomegranate molasses and lobster summer rolls with three dipping sauces.

docs.snippet: Fresh local corn is usually luscious enough to be eaten plain. But butter and salt do not hurt, especially with a new kind of salted butter. Vermont Butter and Cheese's Cultured Butter with Sea Salt Crystals is richly flavored, and the sea salt ad...
docs.abstract: Vermont Butter and Cheese Co introduces new spread--Cultured Butter with Sea Salt Crystals; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Fresh local corn is usually luscious enough to be eaten plain. But butter and salt do not hurt, especially with a new kind of salted butter. Vermont Butter and Cheese's Cultured Butter with Sea Salt Crystals is richly flavored, and the sea salt adds a pleasant textural crunch. It is also excellent spread on dark bread alongside crisp, fresh radishes. It is $6.99 for six ounces at Whole Foods markets. Its little country basket could go right on the table.

docs.snippet: Rwanda's biggest export is coffee, mostly from thousands of small family farms. The Thanksgiving Coffee Company in Fort Bragg, Calif., has started a program to help both the farmers and the endangered mountain gorillas for which Rwanda is famous: ...
docs.abstract: Thanksgiving Coffee Co, Fort Bragg, Calif, imports coffee from Rwanda and donates part of price to Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund International; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Rwanda's biggest export is coffee, mostly from thousands of small family farms. The Thanksgiving Coffee Company in Fort Bragg, Calif., has started a program to help both the farmers and the endangered mountain gorillas for which Rwanda is famous: it buys coffee from a small Fair Trade cooperative near a gorilla habitat, roasts and blends the beans, sells them whole or ground in 12-ounce packages with a picture of a gorilla on the label and donates $2 of the $9.50 price to the Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund International. The blend, called Gorilla Fund Coffee, is full-bodied and rich, with just enough lively acidity. It is available in three grinds at www.thanksgivingcoffee.com or (800) 648-6491. Shipping is extra on orders up to $200; above that, it is free.

headline.main: Wake Up and Save a Gorilla

docs.snippet: Ordering dim sum is usually a pick and point operation, transcending any language barrier, as carts of foods roll by. ''Dim Sum, A Pocket Guide'' by Kit Shan Li (Chronicle Books, $7.95) explains about 50 items, giving Chinese transliterations of t...
docs.abstract: New pocket book Dim Sum, A Pocket Guide describes 50 popular items diners might encounter in dim sum restaurant; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Ordering dim sum is usually a pick and point operation, transcending any language barrier, as carts of foods roll by. ''Dim Sum, A Pocket Guide'' by Kit Shan Li (Chronicle Books, $7.95) explains about 50 items, giving Chinese transliterations of the names and clear, appetizing photographs. Steamed pork dumplings, shrimp dumplings, barbecued pork buns and spring rolls share the pages with duck feet and tripe. But where are the popular pot sticker dumplings? Tea etiquette (taking the lid off the pot when you want a refill) is explained, but not the protocol of different size plates for tallying the bill. There is a diagram for using chopsticks.

headline.main: A Bite-Size Guide To the Dim Sum Cart

docs.snippet: Connoisseurs of Alaskan king crab know there is a world of difference between the delicately succulent fresh kind and the frozen, which is often stringy or waterlogged. For the next month, a few fish markets will sell fresh legs. At Wild Edibles, ...
docs.abstract: Fresh Alaskan king crab legs will be available at several New York City markets for a month; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Connoisseurs of Alaskan king crab know there is a world of difference between the delicately succulent fresh kind and the frozen, which is often stringy or waterlogged. For the next month, a few fish markets will sell fresh legs. At Wild Edibles, 535 Third Avenue (35th Street), the manager, Steve Schaffer, right, sells the crab cooked for $34.95 a pound. (It is also at the Grand Central Market branch.) At the Citarella markets in Manhattan and in the Hamptons the cost is $24.95 a pound for a 6-to-8-pound crab, uncooked, yielding about 3 pounds of meat. At RM, 33 East 60th Street, king crab pot-au-feu is $30 at lunch and $15 extra on the prix-fixe at dinner. Sumile in Greenwich Village and Esca near Times Square are also serving king crab.

docs.snippet: Craig Kanarick is by profession a digital designer and photographer. He is also so fascinated by candy that he collects it and photographs it....
docs.abstract: Craig Kanarick collects and photographs candy; sweet portraits by Kanarick will be on display at Dylan's Candy Bar in Manhattan; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Craig Kanarick is by profession a digital designer and photographer. He is also so fascinated by candy that he collects it and photographs it.

headline.main: The Perfect Candy: Luscious to Look At and No-Cal

docs.snippet: Shochu, the cool drink among the younger set in Japan, is beginning to show up on these shores. Like sake, shochu (or soju), can be made from rice, but more often is based on barley, buckwheat or sweet potatoes. Whereas sake is brewed like beer, s...
docs.abstract: Shochu, cool alcoholic drink favored by Japan's young set, is beginning to show up in America; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Shochu, the cool drink among the younger set in Japan, is beginning to show up on these shores. Like sake, shochu (or soju), can be made from rice, but more often is based on barley, buckwheat or sweet potatoes. Whereas sake is brewed like beer, shochu is distilled like vodka, often twice. At about 50 proof, it has less alcohol than vodka, whether on the rocks or in cocktails like the honeyed shochu at Sushi Samba, and the kumquat sour at Riingo, both in New York. The shochus at left, from Landmark Wines and Spirits, 167 West 23rd Street, range from $10.99 to $24.99 a bottle. I liked two made from barley, the fruity Iichiko and the citrusy Alakey. Zuizen Awamori, similar to shochu and made from rice, had a mushroomy bouquet and a creamy aftertaste. There are also Korean brands, like the syrupy Green, made from sweet potatoes.

headline.main: I'll Have What the Young Japanese Are Having

docs.snippet: There is nothing like chili to take the chill off a wintry Midtown street. Daisy May's BBQ USA, which has a takeout store on 11th Avenue and 46th Street, has rolled out the first two of six snappy-looking chili carts, one at Avenue of the Americas...
docs.abstract: Daisy May's BBQ USA, which has takeout store on 11th Avenue and 46th Street, now has two chili carts in midtown Manhattan; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: There is nothing like chili to take the chill off a wintry Midtown street. Daisy May's BBQ USA, which has a takeout store on 11th Avenue and 46th Street, has rolled out the first two of six snappy-looking chili carts, one at Avenue of the Americas and 50th Street, and the other at Broadway and 39th Street. From 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. on weekdays, the carts sell chili in a 12-ounce cup with a flour tortilla and a garnish of shredded cheese and sour cream, all for $6. The chili, or ''bowl o' red,'' as Adam Perry Lang, below, the chef and owner, calls it, is made with cubes of beef in a forcefully warming sauce that blends three or four kinds of fresh, dried, roasted and smoked chilis. There are no tomatoes. Beans and rice are optional.

headline.main: A Taste of Texas on the Sidewalks of New York

docs.snippet: ASIATE in the Mandarin Oriental New York hotel is the first restaurant to open in the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle. The chef, NORI SUGIE , left, is from Japan but has worked in France and Australia and with Charlie Trotter in Chicago. He ...
docs.abstract: Asiate in Mandarin Oriental, New York, is first restaurant to open in Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle; photo of Nori Sugie, chef (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: ASIATE in the Mandarin Oriental New York hotel is the first restaurant to open in the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle. The chef, NORI SUGIE , left, is from Japan but has worked in France and Australia and with Charlie Trotter in Chicago. He uses local and Japanese ingredients in dishes like lobster in a casserole with a vegetable and shellfish broth, and a green apple and lime parfait with apple soup. The restaurant has 90 seats and is on the 35th floor, the lobby level of the hotel, which occupies 20 floors in the north building of the complex. Glass curtain walls on two sides open the subdued, elegant room, which was designed by Tony Chi, to sweeping views of Central Park and the Upper East and West Sides. After five years, AVENUE, 520 Columbus Avenue (85th Street), has changed its name and its personality. It is now 520, with an American menu -- crab cakes, grilled sea bass, plum crumb tart -- replacing the French bistro fare. The chef, CHRISTINA KELLY, is still in the kitchen.
